tasks.description: German time telling diagram. Clock faces showing: 7:00 (sieben Uhr), 7:15 (Viertel nach sieben), 7:30 (halb acht), 7:45 (Viertel vor acht). Large red warning box highlighting 'halb acht = 6:30!' with explanation that 'halb' refers to the NEXT hour. Visual arrows showing half to next hour. Color-coded examples.
tasks.context: Grammar: Telling time in German - critical halb concept

specs.style: educational diagram, clock faces, large warning highlight, clear color coding

tasks.notes: CRITICAL: Emphasize that halb refers to NEXT hour - major confusion point for learners

tasks.description: Separable verbs structure diagram. Examples showing verb splitting: 'aufstehen' splitting to 'Ich stehe ... auf', 'anfangen' to 'Die Arbeit fängt ... an', 'fernsehen' to 'Ich sehe ... fern'. Arrows showing prefix moving to end. List of common separable prefixes: auf-, an-, ab-, ein-, aus-, mit-, fern-, zurück-. Color-coded verb parts.
tasks.context: Grammar: Separable verbs (Trennbare Verben) - prefix goes to end

specs.style: educational diagram, arrows showing movement, color-coded verb parts, clear examples

tasks.notes: Show clear visual separation and movement of prefix to sentence end

tasks.description: Cultural infographic: German daily schedule and quiet time rules. Timeline showing typical work day: 8-9 start, 12-13 lunch (30min), 17-18 end. Calendar showing Sunday with 'Geschlossen!' (closed shops). Large clock showing 22:00-06:00 with 'RUHEZEIT' (quiet time) in red. Icon of closed shop on Sunday. Warning symbols for noise during quiet hours.
tasks.context: Cultural note: German punctuality, shop hours, quiet time rules (Ruhezeit)

specs.style: infographic timeline, warning icons, practical schedule information, clear time zones

tasks.notes: Critical cultural information - Sunday closures and quiet hours often surprise newcomers
